Comment: This (the exchange variation) is not what I was expecting.  Recently, I've been looking into the Panov-Botvinnik attack and was surprised to see this tamer continuation.  Still, theory holds white retains a slight edge coming out of the opening, so it's hard to blame white for this line.

Pressures the newly undefended pawn.
A very solid structure!
?!  Black overprotects his pawn, but locks in the bishop.  Perhaps Bg4 was a more enterprising continuation, though black does want to be careful not get caught with an uncastled king!
?!  Black overprotects his pawn, but locks in the bishop.  Perhaps Bg4 was a more enterprising continuation, though black does want to be careful not get caught with an uncastled king!
?!  Black overprotects his pawn, but locks in the bishop.  Perhaps Bg4 was a more enterprising continuation, though black does want to be careful not get caught with an uncastled king!
This move puts pressure on the h7-pawn, but maybe this was a bit premature.  Bg5 comes to mind, as the queen certainly can delay development.

That being said, black only has a few pieces left to develop, and the bishop maneuver to d7 doesn't look appetizing.  Instead, black's real purpose is not the h3 pawn, but the e5 break.
?! More consistent would be to try Rd8 and play for the break.  This play is rather passive.
?! More consistent would be to try Rd8 and play for the break.  This play is rather passive.

Though the knight is not pinned, black does not feel comfortable with the bishop on the d8-h4 diagonal.  Finally, this meets black's threat (Bxf6 followed by Bxh7+).  Still, black may face some troubles with the half open g-file.

Though the knight is not pinned, black does not feel comfortable with the bishop on the d8-h4 diagonal.  Finally, this meets black's threat (Bxf6 followed by Bxh7+).  Still, black may face some troubles with the half open g-file.
! The point of white's "tactic" on h7.  Black could not stop both this and the loss of a pawn.  Now, black's king will be feeling the heat.
?!  White can hardly be faulted for bringing his last piece into the game in most situations, but here, white needs to quickly harass the black king before he can consolidate.
?!  White can hardly be faulted for bringing his last piece into the game in most situations, but here, white needs to quickly harass the black king before he can consolidate.
Given a tempo, black rearranges to exploit the kingside himself.  It is, after all, HIS half-open file.
White is moving his pieces to the kingside, but his play comes more slowly than black's.

Better than the overly ambitious plan of playing this rook to h8 and the other rook to g8, I think, because black is already well-poised to exploit the kingside.  The other rook would take unnecessarily long in this plan.
The black king gets out of danger quickly and exposes the g-rook.
The black king gets out of danger quickly and exposes the g-rook.
White threatens the h-pawn and the f-pawn, but should black be worried?
The king is on a file controlled by the opposing rook, but there seems to be no way for white to take advantage of this tactically.
White could have considered Nxh6, but then black would greedily have put his rooks on open h- and g-files.  Scary.
!  Not only defends the pawn, but also keeps the white queen out of the action.
Settling for the best square the she can.  White did seem to have a punishing reply in Nf5+!, where black would probably lose the h-pawn without real compensation.
Black sees that there is no way to defend the plethora of threats and so prepares to shuttle his king over to the queenside without locking in the rook.
